# 1.8 Introduction to Linear Transformations {.unnumbered}

::: {#exr-1-8-eg1c}

## Example 1.c

Let $A=\begin{bmatrix}1 & -3 \\ 3 & 5 \\ -1 & 7\end{bmatrix}, \mathbf{b}=\begin{bmatrix}3 \\ 2 \\ -5\end{bmatrix}$, and define a transformation $T: \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3$ by $T(\mathbf{x})=A\mathbf{x}$. Is there more than one $\mathbf{x}$ whose image under $T$ is $\mathbf{b}$?
:::

::: {.solution}

## Solution to [@exr-1-8-eg1c]

$$\begin{bmatrix}1 & -3 & 3 \\ 3 & 5 & 2 \\ -1 & 7 & -5\end{bmatrix} \sim \begin{bmatrix}1 & -3 & 3 \\ 0 & 1 & -.5 \\ 0 & 0 & 0\end{bmatrix}$$

Since there are no free variables (**the last column is augmented**), there is exactly one $x$ such that $T(\mathbf{x})=\mathbf{b}$.
:::

::: {.remark}

Having a **row** of zeros does not imply that the equation has multiple solutions. It all depends on free variables---namely, the coefficient columns.
:::
